# Question

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

# Solution

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df)
    filtered = df[df[:, "manufacturer"] .== "audi" & (df[:, "model"] .== "a4" | df[:, "model"] .== "a4 quattro"), :]
    insertcols!(filtered, :audi_a4_type => fill(true, size(filtered)[1]))
    return filtered
end
```

The `audi_filter` function takes a DataFrame `df` as input. It filters the dataset to only include rows where the manufacturer is "audi" and either model is "a4" or "a4 quattro" using logical operations. Then, it creates a new column called `audi_a4_type` which has all values set to `true` for all rows in the filtered DataFrame. Finally, it returns this resulting filtered and modified DataFrame.
